text: So these are virtual entities like virtual pets.

text: And
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: human users can interact with them in a virtual environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then in some passages of the novella, there are scenes in which some digians are, as it were, downloaded from this purely virtual environment and are implemented in a physically embodied robot.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: program that is running within this computer simulation and is controlling the purely virtual body is then downloaded into a physically embodied computer and is controlling a physical robot which can interact with its physical environment, non-virtual environment, in the same way in which the virtual agent, the virtual digient
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: interacts with the virtual environment and i find this idea really fascinating and powerful so the novella suggests that these virtual entities are conscious and that they can switch back and forth as it were between this purely virtual environment and the physical non-virtual environment and the idea is that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: these entities remain conscious when they're in the robot, but also when they return to the virtual environment.

text: And so the idea is fascinating to me because it suggests that if you can switch back and forth from the virtual environment to the physical environment and the other direction, it really doesn't matter where the software is implemented.

text: So I start with the free energy principle and I don't want to go into the details.

text: So we start with a description of a physical system.

text: So the X is the physical system and the fundamental assumption is the dynamics, the physical dynamics of this system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: can be decomposed into two components.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we on one hand have a deterministic flow term F and then some noise term, stochastic noise term.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we end up with a stochastic differential equation which describes how the physical system evolves over time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A further assumption is that we can decompose the states of the system
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: into internal states mu, external states eta, sensory states S, and active states A, which together, so sensory and active states together, constitute the blanket states B. And this then is a particular system that can be partitioned into internal and external states separated by blanket states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And a further assumption is that the dynamics of the system can also be partitioned in the following sense that we can decompose this flow term into individual flow terms for the different states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we have a flow term for internal states, mu, and can also describe the dynamics of internal states in terms of such a differential equation here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Okay, so these are just technical fundamental assumptions made by the free energy principle, but then an interesting thing starts here when we look at how else we can describe internal states and the dynamics of internal states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the idea is that we can map internal states mu to probability distributions
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is your formulation in terms of states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then the idea is that at every point in time, the system will be in certain states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So there will be internal states relative to each time point.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we can map each of these states to some probability distribution Q of external states given blanket states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Okay, so we can do that, but then the question is, why should we do that?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the idea is that maybe we can re-describe the flow term, which is essential for characterizing the dynamics of internal states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Can we re-describe this flow terms in terms of the probability distribution encoded by internal states?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the free energy principle answers, yes, we can rewrite this term in terms of a variational free energy functional, which specifies how the probability distribution Q, which is parametrized by mu, and then also how mu changes over time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we can reformulate the physical dynamics of internal states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can rewrite the
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: flow term in terms of variational free energy, or in terms of minimizing variational free energy with respect to a probability distribution encoded by internal states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is then called Bayesian mechanics, and it's called Bayesian mechanics because minimizing variation of the energy
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: involves minimizing a divergence term between the internally encoded probability distribution q and a posterior over external states given blanket states okay um so to to sum this up i will uh
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: give these ideas some labels.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I've already talked about the physical dynamics and these are the dynamics of a particular system described by a stochastic differential equation involving a flow term and a noise term.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we call that a particular system is a system that can be partitioned into internal, external and blanket states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then according to the free energy principle,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: we can re-describe these physical dynamics in terms of as computational dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can reformulate them in terms of a description of the system's internal states mu as performing approximative Bayesian inference by minimizing variation free energy with respect to probability density encoded by mu.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in short, we can reformulate the physical dynamics
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: as a computational process that involves a form of Bayesian inference.

text: Now, a further assumption that I want to make here is that we can capture the computational correlates of consciousness in terms of the computational dynamics as described by the free energy principle.

text: So note that systems that conform to the free energy principle sustain their existence by minimizing variation of free energy, but the reverse does not hold.

text: So you can run simulations of agents that minimize variation of free energy, and you can do that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: on a computer which does not thereby sustain its existence.

text: So this is by
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Prismat out, many theories in the biological sciences are answers to the question, what must things do in order to exist?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The free energy principle turns this question on its head and asks, if things exist, what must they do?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: More formally, if we can define what it means to be something, can we identify the physics or dynamics that a thing must possess?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Jakob Howie
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: puts a similar point as follows.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The free energy principle analyzes the concept of existence of particular self-organizing systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the idea is that continuing to exist, sustaining one's existence means minimizing variational free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so any processes that contribute to minimizing variational free energy thereby contribute to
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the sustained existence of the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But such processes can also be implemented in other ways by different systems which do not thereby sustain their existence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this, I want to suggest, is the crucial difference between systems that merely simulate conscious systems and systems that actually are conscious.

text: I want to introduce a notion of intrinsic computation.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Okay, so from this, I suggest we can derive two necessary conditions for consciousness.

text: One is the flow condition, the causal flow of a physical system's
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then there's a second condition, which I call the existential condition.

text: A physical system sustains its existence by virtue of the by virtue of
speaker: SPEAKER_00

speaker: SPEAKER_00
